body_html: What happens when you constrain to /cpu:0 in the with clause? Do you not get an error exception? As prb12@ commented, there are known subtle semantic differences between the CPU and GPU versions of some kernels. When they involve error handling, like in this case, it's because the GPU kernels are launched asynchronously and there doesn't seem to be a good way of replicating the CPU kernel error handling without compromising performance. As a matter of software engineering practice for code quality, it can be useful to test your models on CPU only to look for this kind of issue.

body: What happens when you constrain to /cpu:0 in the with clause?  Do you not get an error exception?  As prb12@ commented, there are known subtle semantic differences between the CPU and GPU versions of some kernels.  When they involve error handling, like in this case, it's because the GPU kernels are launched asynchronously and there doesn't seem to be a good way of replicating the CPU kernel error handling without compromising performance.  As a matter of software engineering practice for code quality, it can be useful to test your models on CPU only to look for this kind of issue.
